impact-statement: Mutations within the ATPase domain of RIG-I in patients with Singleton-Merten Syndrome prevent ATP-hydrolysis dependent dissociation of RIG-I from double-stranded RNA and lead to unintentional constitutive signaling through increased binding of endogenous RNA.

equal-contrib.equal-contrib: These authors contributed equally to this work

contribution.con1: CL, Planned and performed luciferase assays and co‐IP experiments, purified proteins, performed in vitro assays and wrote the paper
contribution.con2: SM, Purified human ribosomes, carried out ribosome binding studies and analyzed the cryo‐EM structure
contribution.con3: KMJS, Produced measles virus and planned the luciferase assays and co‐IPs
contribution.con4: CCdeOM, Carried out co‐IP experiments and thermal shift assays
contribution.con9: AGS, Supervised the study and critically read the manuscript
contribution.con12: RB, Supervised the study and critically read the manuscript
contribution.con13: KPH, Designed the research, supervised experiments and wrote the paper
contribution.con10: VH, Provided the 293T RIG‐I KO cell line and critically read the manuscript
contribution.con11: KKC, Supervised the study and critically read the manuscript
